# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description

Providing the flag to disable the default encoding the queryParams provided in the route

When the URL is access in angular with http://localhost:4200/test?url=http://abc/item%2F2/3 by default it's redirecting and updating the brower url bar with http://localhost:4200/test?url=http:%2F%2Fabc%2Fitem%2F2%2F3

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->Provide the flag to avoid the defaulf encoding of queryParams.




### Describe alternatives you've considered


Currently I tried to handle this using CustomUrlSerializer but still I am not succeeded

With below implementation still URL in browser shows as http://localhost:4200/test?url=http://abc/item/2/3 and not 
http://localhost:4200/test?url=http://abc/item%2F2/3

```
import {UrlSerializer, UrlTree, DefaultUrlSerializer} from '@angular/router';

export class CustomUrlSerializer implements UrlSerializer {
    public ds = new DefaultUrlSerializer();

    parse(url: any): UrlTree {
        return this.ds.parse(url);
    }

    serialize(tree: UrlTree): any {
        const serializedUrl = this.ds.serialize(tree);
        return serializedUrl
            .replace(/%40/gi, '@')
            .replace(/%3A/gi, ':')
            .replace(/%24/gi, '$')
            .replace(/%2C/gi, ',')
            .replace(/%3B/gi, ';')
            .replace(/%20/gi, '+')
            .replace(/%3D/gi, '=')
            .replace(/%3F/gi, '?')
            .replace(/%2F/gi, '/');
    }
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Avoid default encoding of queryParams in Angular" (#38706)

Issues.Title: refactor(dev-infra): update commit message validation to return validation result
Issues.Body:
Previously, the validateCommitMessage function ran validation and logged the results.
The validateCommitMessage function now returns an object containing the validation
results and the cli action functions are instead responsible for logging the results.

This is being done as a prefactor for a change which allows for commit message
hook validation to be either a blocking error or a warning.

Issues.Title: fix(localize): do not expose NodeJS typings in $localize runtime code
Issues.Body:
A recent change to `@angular/localize` brought in the `AbsoluteFsPath` type
from the `@angular/compiler-cli`. But this brought along with it a reference
to NodeJS typings - specifically the `FileSystem` interface refers to the
`Buffer` type from NodeJS.

This affects compilation of `@angular/localize` code that will be run in
the browser - for example projects that reference `loadTranslations()`.
The compilation breaks if the NodeJS typings are not included in the build.
Clearly it is not desirable to have these typings included when the project
is not targeting NodeJS.

This commit replaces references to the NodeJS `Buffer` type with `Uint8Array`,
which is available across all platforms and is actually the super-class of
`Buffer`.

Fixes #38692
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(localize): do not expose NodeJS typings in $localize runtime code" (#38700)

Issues.Title: fix(localize): install `@angular/localize` in `devDependencies` by default
Issues.Body:
Previously this package was installed in the default `dependencies` section
of `package.json`, but this meant that its dependencies are treated as
dependencies of the main project - Babel, for example.

Generally, $localize` is not used at runtime - it is compiled out by the
translation tooling, so there is no need for it to be a full dependency.

This commit changes the default location of the package to be the
`devDependencies` section, but gives the user a prompt to choose
otherwise.

Fixes #38329
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(localize): install `@angular/localize` in `devDependencies` by default" (#38680)

Issues.Title: Time zone globally
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description
I would like a global time zone setting for the date pipe. Currently, the date pipe gets a time zone as an optional parameter if there is no such parameter then gets the current zone of the client. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
We could achieve that with an injection token just like the LOCALE one.

I could implement that. My plan is to create a new injection token called TIME_ZONE in the **/i18n/tokens.ts**. Then we could inject that token in the application_module.ts with a default value your local time zone. Once we have that we could inject that token in the date pipe and pass that value to the **formatDate** method.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Time zone globally" (#38696)

Issues.Title: loadTranslations from @angular/localize dependes on Node.js
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/localize ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 10.0.x ### Description I was using "loadTranslations" to dynamically load translations at runtime. Example: ``` import { loadTranslations } from '@angular/localize'; loadTranslations(window['LOCALIZATION_MESSAGES']); ``` This worked until Angular 10.1.0. Now build breaks with this error message: ``` ERROR in node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system/src/types.d.ts:37:43 - error TS2591: Cannot find name 'Buffer'. Do you need to install type definitions for node? Try `npm i @types/node` and then add `node` to the types field in your tsconfig. readFileBuffer(path: AbsoluteFsPath): Buffer; ................. ................. ``` The problem is that "loadTranslations" use "MessageId" and "TargetMessage" (https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/fdea1804d6d46d33c71640972ff45a8d5cc82f8b/packages/localize/src/utils/src/messages.ts#L40 , that are declared in messages.ts that use: ``` import { AbsoluteFsPath } from '@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system'; ``` https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/fdea1804d6d46d33c71640972ff45a8d5cc82f8b/packages/localize/src/utils/src/messages.ts#L9 So it depends on Node.js (therefore, it cannot be used in a browser). The problem is just with typings. There is simple solution. Divide messages.ts into 2 files (one that contains types that are dependent on Node and the second that is independent). A clear and concise description of the problem... ## üî• Exception or Error 



ERROR in node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system/src/types.d.ts:37:43 - error TS2591: Cannot find name 'Buffer'. Do you need to install type definitions for node? Try `npm i @types/node` and then add `node` to the types field in your tsconfig.

37     readFileBuffer(path: AbsoluteFsPath): Buffer;
                                             ~~~~~~
node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system/src/types.d.ts:38:52 - error TS2591: Cannot find name 'Buffer'. Do you need to install type definitions for node? Try `npm i @types/node` and then add `node` to the types field in your tsconfig.

38     writeFile(path: AbsoluteFsPath, data: string | Buffer, exclusive?: boolean): void;
                                                      ~~~~~~
node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system/src/node_js_file_system.d.ts:10:43 - error TS2591: Cannot find name 'Buffer'. Do you need to install type definitions for node? Try `npm i @types/node` and then add `node` to the types field in your tsconfig.

10     readFileBuffer(path: AbsoluteFsPath): Buffer;
                                             ~~~~~~
node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/file_system/src/node_js_file_system.d.ts:11:52 - error TS2591: Cannot find name 'Buffer'. Do you need to install type definitions for node? Try `npm i @types/node` and then add `node` to the types field in your tsconfig.

11     writeFile(path: AbsoluteFsPath, data: string | Buffer, exclusive?: boolean): void;
                                                      ~~~~~~

Issues.Title: 10.1.0 Router empty path regression
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Summary Upgrading to Angular 10.1.0 does not stop routing on the first matching route entry. ### Is this a regression? Yes, this used to work in all previous versions of Angular (from v2 onwards). ### Description Previous versions of Angular allowed routes to be defined in a prioritized order. As per the screenshot below, we direct the route to specific module if a path is provided, however if no path is provided, we route to the main application module. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23112857/92070529-a0dc9a00-edef-11ea-9814-99c1c2b15235.png) It appears that V10.1.0 now triggers the last path (the one highlighted in the screenshot above) even if the other paths load first. In our case, if we try to login via the auth path, it first shows the login page for a brief few milliseconds and then it tries to navigate to the main module via the `path: ''` entry but this fails the auth check and redirects back to the auth module and this cycle then repeats forever. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Removing the highlighted line in the above screenshot stops the repeated loading from occurring. But this isn't a fix as it stops our app from working as well. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.1.0
Node: 12.10.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 10.1.0
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

-----------------------------------------------------------

Issues.Title: Angular SwPush subscription refresh
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
 This feature request is for @angular/service-worker


### Description
Using Angular's SwPush, we are looking for:
1) A way to refresh old or expired web push subscriptions. The standard explains how the browser is expected to do this automatically (https://www.w3.org/TR/push-api/#subscription-refreshes) and fire a "pushsubscriptionchange" event, but I am under the impression this event cannot be handled through Angular's SwPush after going through ngsw-worker.js (I might be wrong?). 
2) Once a subscription refresh is made, we need to handle it by updating the subscription on the app server so that new notifications are delivered to the new subscription instead of the expired one.

This has to happen in the service worker, since users may not run the app for a while.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Is it possible for the Angular service worker to take care of automatic subscription refresh and optionally post the old and new subscriptions to an endpoint that is specified in ngsw-config.json?


### Describe alternatives you've considered
1) Ignoring the problem of expired subscriptions => but our use case requires a high degree of reliability in delivering push notifications when the user is expecting them.
2) Modifying the source of ngsw-worker.js => but it seems too hacky for a fairly standard requirement.
3) Use the application code to do the refresh the subscription every time the user runs the app => users may not run the app in a while.

Best wishes,
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular SwPush subscription refresh" (#38690)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): correct confusion between field and property names
Issues.Body:
The `R3TargetBinder` accepts an interface for directive metadata which
declares types for `input` and `output` objects. These types convey the
mapping between the property names for an input or output and the
corresponding field name on the component class. Due to `R3TargetBinder`'s
requirements, this mapping was specified with property names as keys and
field names as values.

However, because of duck typing, this interface was accidentally satisifed
by the opposite mapping, of field names to property names, that was produced
in other parts of the compiler. This form more naturally represents the data
model for inputs.

Rather than accept the field -> property mapping and invert it, this commit
introduces a new abstraction for field to property mappings which is
bidirectional, eliminating the ambiguous plain object type. This mapping can
be used to satisfy both the needs of the binder (property -> field) as well
as those of the template type-checker (field -> property).

A new test ensures that the input/output metadata produced by the compiler
during analysis is directly compatible with the binder via this unambiguous
new interface.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler): correct confusion between field and property names" (#38685)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): ensure that a declaration is available in type-to-value conversion
Issues.Body:
The type-to-value conversion could previously crash if a symbol was
resolved that does not have any declarations, e.g. because it's imported
from a missing module. This would typically result in a semantic
TypeScript diagnostic and halt further compilation, therefore not
reaching the type-to-value conversion logic. In Bazel however, it turns
out that Angular semantic diagnostics are requested even if there are
semantic TypeScript errors in the program, so it would then reach the
type-to-value conversation and crash.

This commit fixes the unsafe access and adds a test that ignores the
TypeScript semantic error, effectively replicating the situation as
experienced under Bazel.

Fixes #38670
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler-cli): ensure that a declaration is available in type-to-value conversion" (#38684)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler): Parse and recover on incomplete opening HTML tags
Issues.Body:
Let's say we have a code like ```html 123 ``` Currently this gets parsed into a tree with the element tag `div` doesn't close an element is emitted. - A consumer of the parse tree using it for editor services is unable to provide correct completions for the opening `` tag. This patch attempts to fix both issues by instead parsing the code into the same tree that would be parsed for `
123`. In particular, we do this by optimistically scanning an open tag as usual, but if we do not notice a terminating '>', we mark the tag as "incomplete". A parser then emits an error for the incomplete tag and adds a synthetic (recovered) element node to the tree with the incomplete open tag's name. What's the downside of this? For one (well, two), breaking changes.
  1. The first breaking change is that `<` symbols that are ambiguously text or opening tags will be parsed as opening tags instead of text in element bodies. Take the code ```html

    a ``` Clearly we cannot have the best of both worlds, and this patch chooses to swap the parsing strategy to support the new feature. Of course, `<` can still be inserted as text via the `<` entity.

  2. The second breaking change is that elements can no longer be parsed inside an interpolation. For example, ```html {{ a d}} ``` Would previously be parsed to include `` as an opening tag, but now it will be parsed as equivalent to `a < b && c > d`. I am not sure why the former parse tree was valid, since elements have no semantic meaning in an interpolation to the best of my knowledge.
Part of #38596 ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Feature ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [x] Yes

Issues.Title: Named router outlets which use the normal uri to navigate
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router


### Description
Named router outlets use their own url part and can not use the full url.
In many cases it's senseful to have multiple components with content according to the url 
and it would safe much code if you wouldnt need to have just one primary route outlet where you need to change all of the childs contents.

As example:
your site has a banner at the top of the page, than a navigation bar, and below that some content.
The banner should always be fitted to the content.
Thats where you could use a named outlet for the banner which uses the same url as the contents (primary) outlet.

Right now you would have to make the whole page the primary outlet, and add the navigationbar to all routed components.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Named outlets routes should have an option to use the main url like this:
`{ path: '**', outlet: 'navigation', component: MainNavigationComponent, useMainUrl: true }`
and if it's set to true, it should use the same value to compare as the main outlet would use.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Named router outlets which use the normal uri to navigate" (#38678)

**BREAKING CHANGE**: This moves to using `Symbol.for` to create the symbol instance. It's _possible_ that some runtimes that support `Symbol` do not support `Symbol.for`. Therefor, I'm marking this as a breaking change. If you find that you hit this issue, please report it. You can work around it by polyfilling `Symbol.for`.

</details>

Issues.Title: Creation of workspace failed
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I only tried Angular CLI 10.0.8. ### Description After I had created a new VM with Ubuntu 18.04, I also installed 1. node 12.18.3 2. npm 6.14.6 3. angular CLI 10.0.8 I followed the instructions on the official site (https://angular.io/guide/setup-local), but the execution of `ng new my-app` failed every time! After some minutes of downloading some packages the error message was always the following: ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Take a plain Ubuntu 18.04 VM and install 1. node 12.18.3 2. npm 6.14.6 3. angular CLI 10.0.8 After this was successful just type `ng new my-app` and wait for the error. 

npm ERR! code ENOENT
npm ERR! syscall open
npm ERR! path /development/my-app/node_modules/copy-webpack-plugin/node_modules/cacache/package.json.3367901514
npm ERR! errno -2
npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/development/my-app/node_modules/copy-webpack-plugin/node_modules/cacache/package.json.3367901514'
npm ERR! enoent This is related to npm not being able to find a file.
npm ERR! enoent
I have done this 4 times with a fresh VM and the result was always the same. ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment Output of `ng version`: 

Angular CLI: 10.0.8
Node: 12.18.3
OS: linux x64

Angular:
...
Ivy Workspace:

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.1000.8
@angular-devkit/core         10.0.8
@angular-devkit/schematics   10.0.8

Issues.Title: ng build --watch build all bundles instead delta bundle
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes ng build --watch should produce only delta bundle, and not build the whole project on any change. ### Description when using ng build --watch flag, I expect the behavior to be as same as it was in previous version: If the main code changed, the build --watch should produce only new main.js bundle, if the styles changed, should produce new styles.js bundle. Actual - the ng build --watch produce all bundles in each change (change on main/styles etc.) ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: [BUG]: Regression build after upgrade to Angular 10 (Module not found: Error: Recursion in resolving)
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/cli ### Is this a regression? Yes, because our projects with Angular 8, 9 correct works ### Description We use a shared directory to node modules on disk (for improved sharing space on CI). .yarnrc (for our ng8, ng9 apps) ``` --modules-folder /var/tmp/yarn/ng10/node_modules/ --cache-folder /var/tmp/yarn/cache/ ``` Therefore, we refer to modules via a symlink: package.json (for our ng8, ng9 apps) ```json "scripts": { "preinstall": "mkdir -p /var/tmp/yarn/ng10/node_modules/ && rm -f node_modules", "postinstall": "ln -s /var/tmp/yarn/ng10/node_modules/ node_modules && yarn ngcc --async" } ``` But after upgrade to Angular 10, everything stop working. Now it is required that the node_modules directory was created locally. Is this a bug angular compiler? ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/splincode/ng-10-build-failed ```bash git clone https://github.com/splincode/ng-10-build-failed.git cd ng-10-build-failed ``` ```bash yarn install yarn build # not working ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: CSS optimization breaks when :host-context is included
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I have a CSS file that is shared between two components, one that uses default encapsulation and one that uses NONE. I have two lines in the CSS as follows: ``` .darkMode .myLogo { color: white; } :host-context(.darkMode) .myLogo { color: white; } ``` This works fine with dev/unoptimized builds. However, when done with a prod/optimized build the resulting CSS combines the two selectors: ``` .darkMode .myLogo,:host-context(.darkMode) .myLogo{color:white}``` The selector is essentially ignored by the browser. For the component using default encapsulation it similarly works fine regardless of whether optimized or not. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error

Angular CLI: 10.0.8
node: 10.16.3
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 10.0.14

Issues.Body:
Hi. Using the `MatTab` component I am able to show my tabs. There are many tabs so the arrows are visible to navigate through the tabs.
I have implemented myself a 'home' button so that pressing this button the `selectedIndex` will become 0 (first tab will be active).

The problem I have is that if the `selectedIndex` is 0, then I use the arrows to navigate again and the zeroIndex tab is not visible anymore and then I press the home button the transition will not work, so basically the button does nothing if the `selectedIndex` is zero before clicking the button.

Here's a picture that may help understand:

Issues.Title: bug(material): Angular 10 - Columns cannot be dragged and dropped in Material Table anymore
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1.  In Angular 7 one can make the columns of a material table drag and drop-able to change their display order: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-mat-table-columns-draggable
This works fine in Angular 7
2.  In Angular 10 the approach does not work anymore:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-jnnkb2?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftable-basic-example.ts
3. It seems that in Angular 10 for some reason the drop event is not triggered anymore (the drag event is triggered)
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
I expect to see the same behavior as in the Angular 7 example. Columns can be dragged and dropped to change their order in the table.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
The columns can be dragged in Angular 10, but the drop event is never triggered. This means the logic to reorder the columns in a table is not triggered and thus their order is not changed. Even worse, the column header seem to hang around somewhere.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.1
- CDK/Material: 10.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows, Macos. Ubuntu not tested
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(material): Angular 10 - Columns cannot be dragged and dropped in Material Table anymore" (#20495)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-expansion-panel): Component never use background color from the theme always fallback to default
Issues.Body:
Overriding `card` background color in a theme does not affect the background color of the `mat-expansion-panel` compnent

#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-vinxqi?file=src/styles.scss

#### Expected Behavior

Background color of the `mat-expansion-panel` should come from `$theme.background.card`


#### Actual Behavior

Background lookup is done in `$theme.color.background.card` which does not exist in a theme and therefore always fallback to the default value.


#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.0
- CDK/Material: 10.1.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs

#### Details

I believe the issue is located in the `@mixin mat-expansion-panel-theme`
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/10.1.x/src/material/expansion/_expansion-theme.scss#L103

If a theme is passed as parameter, The `color` config is extracted from the theme using `mat-get-color-config` and then passed to `mat-expansion-panel-color`

But the `mat-expansion-panel-color` seems to expect a theme object as input, not just the color sub key. It tries to extract the background and foreground config of the theme:
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/10.1.x/src/material/expansion/_expansion-theme.scss#L11
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-expansion-panel): Component never use background color from the theme always fallback to default" (#20490)

Issues.Title: fix(datepicker): remove red shadow from invalid range inputs in Firefox
Issues.Body:
Firefox automatically adds a red `box-shadow` to invalid inputs. These changes remove it from the inner range inputs since their invalid state is shown through the `mat-form-field`.

Fixes #20483.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(datepicker): remove red shadow from invalid range inputs in Firefox" (#20489)

Issues.Title: fix(material/snack-bar): flaky screen reader announcements for NVDA/JAWS
Issues.Body:
Fixes a bug where NVDA won't announce polite snack bars and JAWS won't announce any.
This is because the live region (snack-bar-container) was added to the DOM, marked as a live
region, and content was added to it in the same operation. Some screen readers require the live
region to be added to the DOM, some time to pass, then content can be added. Now the snack bar
content is added to an aria-hidden div then, 100ms later, moved to a div with aria-live defined.
This won't cause any visual changes and keeps the snack bar content available immediatly after
opening. Also, no longer using the alert or status roles. Instead just using aria-live as testing
showed that NVDA will double announce with the alert role and JAWS won't announce any button text.

BREAKING CHANGE: matSnackBarHarness.getRole() replaced with .getAriaLive() due to using aria-live
rather than the alert and status roles.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/snack-bar): flaky screen reader announcements for NVDA/JAWS" (#20487)

Issues.Title: Datepicker - Firefox displaying red box-shadow when "required" attribute added to matEndDate input
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-gp6jmx?file=src%2Fapp%2Fdate-range-picker-forms-example.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add mat-date-range-input 
2. Add required attribute to the matEndDate input
3. View in Firefox. When no dates have been selected, a red border appears on the end date input. 

`<mat-form-field appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Enter a date range</mat-label>
  <mat-date-range-input [formGroup]="range" [rangePicker]="picker" >
    <input matStartDate formControlName="start" placeholder="Start date" required >
    <input matEndDate formControlName="end" placeholder="End date" required>
  </mat-date-range-input>
  <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
  <mat-date-range-picker #picker></mat-date-range-picker>

  <mat-error *ngIf="range.controls.start.hasError('matStartDateInvalid')">Invalid start date</mat-error>
  <mat-error *ngIf="range.controls.end.hasError('matEndDateInvalid')">Invalid end date</mat-error>
</mat-form-field>
`
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Shouldn't be able to see the input border. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/138858/92035806-1bd87e80-ed24-11ea-8522-a97ccab111b2.png)

#### Actual Behavior

In Firefox, can see the red required box shadow until 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/138858/92035793-124f1680-ed24-11ea-8269-a14f9c7347ac.png)

#### Environment

- Angular:  10.1.0
- CDK/Material: 10.1.2
- Browser(s): Firefox 79, Firefox 80
- Operating System:  MacOs and Windows.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Datepicker - Firefox displaying red box-shadow when "required" attribute added to matEndDate input" (#20483)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove deprecated APIs for v11
Issues.Body:
Removes the deprecated APIs for v11 from `material/core`. Also fixes that the MDC-based form field doesn't support the global `floatLabel` option.

BREAKING CHANGES:
* `MAT_LABEL_GLOBAL_OPTIONS` from `material/core` has been removed. Import `MAT_FORM_FIELD_DEFAULT_OPTIONS` from `material/form-field` instead.
* `FloatLabelType` from `material/core` has been removed. Import `FloatLabelType` from `material/form-field` instead.
* `LabelOptions` from `material/core` has been removed. Import `MatFormFieldDefaultOptions` from `material/form-field` instead.
* `MAT_DATE_LOCALE_PROVIDER` has been removed, because it is no longer needed since MAT_DATE_LOCALE has been changed to a scoped injectable. If you are importing and providing this in your code you can simply remove it.
* `MatLineSetter` class has been removed. Use the `setLines` function instead.
* `hammer` property from `GranularSanityChecks` has been removed, because it isn't being used anymore.
* `document` parameter of the `MatCommonModule` constructor is now required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): remove deprecated APIs for v11" (#20479)

Issues.Title: refactor(material/list): fix action list CSS styles conflict with MDC-based list
Issues.Body:
The Angular Material action list has been styled using an element selector,
instead of using the corresponding CSS class. This meant that the MDC-based
list seemed to have a working action list, but in reality it was just working due
to the leaked styles from the non-MDC list.

This fixes the selector in the Angular Material list, and adds the necessary styles
for the action list to the MDC list styles.

Note: I used the `refactor` type as I wasn't sure whether we want this to show up for the non-MDC list in the changelog.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(material/list): fix action list CSS styles conflict with MDC-based list" (#20477)

Issues.Title: bug(icon): custom directive cannot set svgIcon for mat-icon
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

_`svgIcon` does not seem to work with Stackblitz, providing repo instead._

Steps to reproduce:
1. Clone https://github.com/klemenoslaj/mat-icon-svg-not-applied
2. Install dependencies using `yarn`
3. Execute `ng serve`
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

I tried to create a custom directive that would programmatically assign some icon name to the `svgIcon` input of `mat-icon`, depending on some global icon mapping configuration.
This normally works for any component and I'd expect it should for `mat-icon` too.

Example:
```html
<mat-icon [iconFor]="object"></mat-icon>
```

```ts
@Directive({
  selector: 'mat-icon[iconFor]',
})
export class IconForDirective {
  @Input()
  set iconFor(obj: SomeInterface) {
    this._matIcon.svgIcon = _iconMap[obj.type];
  }

  constructor(
    @Inject(ICON_MAPPING_TOKEN)
    private readonly _iconMap: SomeIconMapping,
    private readonly _matIcon: MatIcon,
  ) {}
}
```

#### Actual Behavior

The behavior described above does not work with `mat-icon`, because the relevant logic is in `ngOnChanges` hook of `mat-icon`, which does not get triggered, unless at least one `Input` is present on the host component.

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4f1238f84791f4193b5dfc8d9cbef76f04ee36d6/src/material/icon/icon.ts#L229-L264

##### Workaround (ugly):

Instead of
```html
<mat-icon [iconFor]="object"></mat-icon>
```

add dummy/empty `svgIcon`
```html
<mat-icon [iconFor]="object" svgIcon></mat-icon>
```

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.14
- CDK/Material: 10.1.3
- Browser(s): any
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): any

---

NOTE: I can submit the PR for this, but would like some thoughts on that, maybe it's expected like this for some reason.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(icon): custom directive cannot set svgIcon for mat-icon" (#20470)
